Topic.Title: Can't be squeezed out of longer dated put spreads, unlike a short position

Message.Msg: Sybil - up on average 16% of sybs in entire retail trade account annually 2010-2012 - booked az gainz and paid at tax filing. Straight long / short trading: no optionz. This while many many optionz crack headz got murdered on decayed expensive premiumz in volitility, time, and direction.... Since 2011, sybs haz been taking down bearish bets and patiently trading around a core position where optionz crackheadz doing the same have been systemically and brutally muderered. 2008: bear sternz, lehman, aig all could not honor the massive liabilitiez they wrote in optionz, swaps, and other derivativez - the government stepped in and backed the bets for them. 2015 will not be the same, the gvt will not step in az they will not be able to . Where straight tradez will be honored in 2015 when the circuit breakerz kick back on, contractual optionz bets and the etfs that are loaded with them will not be.

Message.Title: AMZN's problem is clear....The Cloud business is losing big market share to Microsoft
Message.Msg: I was long confused my AMZN's ridiculous stock price and how could a profitless "retailer" trade at such a huge valuation. Well, the retail business does have a great deal of value, but not what the stock price indicates. The primo valuation has been given to AMZN because of its "Cloud" business, which has grown rapidly and has the largest market share in the industry. This is a very high p/e business due to its growth rate and investor enthusiasm over the sector. AMZN's cloud business has not however helped much with AMZN's overall profits. Now, Microsoft has attacked this market with a vengeance and is taking away huge market shares. MSFT has already captured 25% share and analysts say that this figure is going to 35% pronto. This is a huge negative for AMZN and positive for MSFT. Look at the two stock prices. MSFT isn't going up because of its PC activities. Now AMZN will be losing its primo rating and valuation from the cloud sector. The retail business while growing does not provide much support for the share price. This story is unfolding rapidly, but like APPL and Samsung, it will take several months to full play out. Over that time, look for AMZN shares to take a beating.

Message.Msg: I actually agree with you on this somewhat. I learned the lesson after having bought a lot of Call and Put options for a couple of years and losing probably 90% of the time. Howvever, I don't completely agree with you. I have been in stocks (both long and short) that had almost zero options being traded in them, and I bought or shorted such stocks based upon fundamentals, and yet the stocks still very often go against your position (at least for very long periods of time). So your rationale does not always hold true.

Topic.Title: Let the word go forth

Message.Msg: LOL funny but very true sadly. Imagine a market where bids and asks are set by true supply and demand, and prices moved accordingly. Ahhh to dream. Instead stocks go up when the right people are in, and the company is executing to some extent. Or stocks go down when the right people are out, and the company isn't to some extent. But unless both are true for either case, you don't get the logical result, you get the opposite. Welcome to Wall St.

Topic.Title: Where's the poster who was bragging about his PUTS doing well?

Message.Msg: I don't have a problem with you posting whatever you like. I'm just trying to point out to you the futility of you telling others of what you did or plan to do. In fact, if you are conspiracy believer or potential conspiracy believer, you may want to consider it contrary to your own best interest to publicly disclose your current positions and future trading strategies. After all, the NYSE floor traders don't go around publicly disclosing their trades and strategies. In fact, I'm not sure anyone knows anything about what they are doing all day. It's all veiled in great secrecy. Have you ever seen a story that tells the details what those floor traders are actually doing all day long in precise details?

Topic.Title: Let the word go forth

Message.Msg: I think that no stock gets bid up because of anything the company does. It gets bid up because of the ARBITRARY decision to bid it up by those with enough money to make the price go up. Well, not completely arbitrary. There is some perceived self-interest on the part of the bidder upper. That is, such a person wants to prove the masses that one cannot expect a stock to go up due to fundamental rationale and analysis, and thus everyone needs to pay someone else with "mystical wisdom" to buy the "right stocks" for them at the "right time." That's it, period. That is what got the likes of the fundamentally bankrupt AMR bid up from $1/share to $40/share, even while oiil prices were soaring (and yes, AMR eventually went bk, but not before eliminating the "naysayers" by way of driving up the stock prices and squeezing out the naysayers first). Worse, the likes of NWAC got bid up from 50 cents/share to $6/share even AFTER it was already bk! Then there was GENI that got bid up from $5/sahre to $50/sahre, and almost never had a down day in two years, despite the fact that "everyone" on the GENI board was continually saying that the company was a scam. And on and on and on and on. It's all about the upbidders trying to prove to the masses that fundamentals do not mean anything, i.e. you cannot buy and short stocks based upon doing your own fundamental analysis, i.e. you need to pay a guru to do it for you. PERIIOD.

I think MSFT considers AMZN its competition? You realize that MSFT is already matching AMZN prices and is in a better position than AMZN to further cut prices. Btw, you know MSFT owns Windows and SQL Server right? A large number of cloud servers do make use of, you got it, Windows and SQL Server. AMZN has to pay for Windows and SQL Server licenses, MSFT does not. AMZN got lucky with the sales tax regulations. That luck is going away.

Topic.Title: AMZN's problem is clear....The Cloud business is losing big market share to Microsoft

Message.Msg: The problem with "leading" is that you end up with obsolete hardware. It's not always good to be "leading" esp. if you don't know how to be profitable. Leading and losing money is simply you burning money to light a path for the competition to know how they can beat you. Yes, you have a certain customer base, but all key customers would have already planned to ensure their platform are cloud agonistic. I am sure GOOG and MSFT already have plans and tools in place to help key customers transition from AMZN.

Message.Title: Ponzi will be exposed soon enough...
Message.Msg: Look at the current cash position. What do you think will happen to accrued liabilities (gift cards) if the economy really starts to weaken? Higher rather of redemption coupled with slower sales growth or negative sales growth. Increases in days payable and accrued liabilities provided almost $2.7B since Q1 2012. Despite that, Amazon had to raise $3B in Q4 2012 to avoid a real cash crunch (the offices only needed half of the raise...). There are so many glaring issues with Amazon's current economic model. I truly wish all the pumper analysts had to invest 25-50% of their wealth in scams like Amazon until they changed their rating to sell (at which it could be redeployed to a "buy"). There wouldn't be one buys rating on the Street at these prices. But, when playing with other people's money... Which is why retail doesn't trust Wall Street.

Topic.Title: AMZN's problem is clear....The Cloud business is losing big market share to Microsoft

Message.Msg: This is particularly true with the more power efficient servers coming along and with some other interesting. The reality is that only Google has control of a key strategic assets that will not really be subject to Moore's law type competition and its deflationary effects. Google bought those assets for pennies on the $ because it was truly forward thinking (and yet analysts beat on it for years afterward for "lack of focus") whereas Amazon sinks billions into non-distinctive (redundant at the macro level) distribution centers that do not meaningfully improve its cost structure... Google will have a security and cost advantage on enterprise cloud over the long term.

Topic.Title: Selling puts

Message.Msg: I think what JC is saying is that the current environment, where implied volatility is lower than historical volatility, does not make for a good time to write puts. However, I think there's always ways to generate the type of income you're talking about with options with very little risk.

Message.Title: I don't actuallly blame the big boys for wanting to beat retail shorts
Message.Msg: The name of their game is to beat as many retail shorts (and longs) as they can. Think about it, what would YOU do if you were in their shoes? Of course if retail is buying from you, you dump. And of course if retail is shorting to you, you pump. It's the only thing they can do. And I was taught to never judge someone else if you are not in their shoes.
